Discovering Your Own Definition of Potential

The will to win the desire to succeed the urge to reach your full potential.. PERIOD these are the keys that will unlock the door to personal excellence. confucius

What does the word potential mean to you personally

The Oxford English Dictionary defines potential as possible as opposed to actual having or showing the capacity to develop into something in the future latent prospective. this definition is useful but it doesnt tell us how one can actually discover and reach their full potential PERIOD

Tips to Help You Define and Discover Your Potential

Am I reaching my full potential is not the same as asking How do I get to the top Instead potential asks you to look at how you personally define success and then to explore and find your unique and individual path to get there PERIOD

Review the following tips to help you discover your own definition of potential and what success and potential truly mean to you PERIOD

 PERIOD Know Yourself

Assess your current skills and performance by writing down some of your greatest strengths and weaknesses PERIOD This involves necessary reflection asking for specific feedback and being receptive to input from hopefully a variety of people in a variety of contexts PERIOD This should be an ongoing process and it will take time humility and a willingness to confront your shortcomings and fears PERIOD However people can and do change and improve after recognizing both their strengths and weaknesses PERIOD Make the decision to change and grow and it will help you move forward PERIOD

 PERIOD Excel at Critical Tasks

It is difficult to succeed and to reach your potential if you dont excel at central and necessary tasks PERIOD This sounds simple but many people fail to identify activities that lead to success in their lives whether that be personal academic or workplace success PERIOD Identifying these tasks can assist you in matching priorities with success and can foster discipline better time management and confidence PERIOD

 PERIOD Demonstrate Character and Leadership

Character and leadership often make the difference between good performance and great performance PERIOD Pillars of good character include trustworthiness

respect responsibility fairness caring and citizenship to name a few PERIOD Leaders are willing to do things for others without regard to whats in it for them PERIOD Being a leader also means being willing to speak up even if you have to express an unpopular view PERIOD Spend more time thinking about who you truly are and what you truly believe rather than what others want you to be or say PERIOD

 PERIOD Set Goals and Benchmarks

Narrow in on what youd like to accomplish even if these are just shortterm goals PERIOD Take baby steps brainstorm ways to get to where you want to be and seek out mentors PERIOD Keep a success list to remind yourself that you are good enough PERIOD Dont ever think your accomplishments are too small to be proud of PERIOD It is easy to think that when you compare yourself to others so try not to PERIOD

 PERIOD Dont Doubt Yourself

Although this is super clich you really need to believe in yourself to reach your potential PERIOD You are good enough to do anything you want in life PERIOD Remember that you are good enough and never give up PERIOD If you want something do whatever it takes to get it PERIOD As Dori from Finding Nemo says sometimes you have to just keep swimming PERIOD

Take Advantage of Career Services

Located directly above the WVU Bookstore in the Mountainlair Career Services is a Universitywide resource for undergraduate and graduate students as well as alumni PERIOD They are here to help students and alumni explore and identify career goals develop professional skills and discover employment and continuing education opportunities PERIOD

If you need some help reaching your full professional potential visit WVU Career Services in the Mountainlair MondayFriday  a.m PERIOD to  p.m PERIOD

Contact Information   careerservicesmail.wvu.edu  careerservices.wvu.edu PERIOD

Courtesy of Harvard Business Review Reaching Your PotentialRobert Steven Kaplan
